title: Sitʼkunaa G̱eeyí Daat Shkalneek / The Story of Glacier-Bidding Bay
author: Seidayaa / Elizabeth Nyman

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Wé Sitʼkunaa G̱eeyí tle yéi áwé yatee, latín wé— yáadu á wé sítʼ anax̱ haat kaawa.ayi yé tle tle yóo aax̱ ḵukayaxát.
sentences.sentence_english: Sitʼkunaa G̱eeyí (Glacier-bidding Bay) is like this, see— here is where the glacier moves this way; the valley continues like this.

sentences.sentence_english: This is Yanyeidí Xʼaayí (Yanyeidí Point)— they also call it Sítʼ Xʼaayí (Swede Point)— it extends out toward [where the] Taku Lodge [is].

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Á áwé has akanéek áwé wé ax̱ éesh wé du húnx̱u tín wooch een, wé sítʼ oon yoo x̱ʼadudli.átk, ḵaa x̱ʼaya.áx̱ch yóo has x̱ʼayaḵá, wé Naada.éiyaach tsu aax̱ daak wullaayí yéeyich á aax̱ áwé has awsikóo.
sentences.sentence_english: This is what my father and his brothers would discuss together: the glacier could be spoken to and it would understand what it was told, they said, because Naada.éiyaa [had let the blood drain from the slave’s body and] the ice had receded, melting away from it. This is how they knew about it.
